DIV1.P: REASONS Concerning the Immediate Demolishing OF DUNKIRK: BEING A Serious Enquiry INTO THE State and Condition of that Affair.

Q.L: O miseri, quae tanta Insania, Cives?

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for John Morphew, near Stationers Hall. 1713. Price 6 d.

DIV1.HEAD: REASONS Concerning the Immediate Demolishing OF DUNKIRK, &c.
DIV1.P: THEY who undertake so unpo∣pular an Argument as this of the Demolishing of Dunkirk is, must be prepared to be very ill treated by those who are on the other side; who, besides what Arguments they think fit to use, are always ready to quar∣rel with what they may not approve.

Be it known to such, That the Writer of these Sheets was ever a Protestant,
and truly jealous for the Protestants a∣gainst the Popish Interest: He has been so far from a French Party, that he was ever against all Parties: And as for the Pretender, he has willingly and unfeign∣edly abjur'd him.

Yet he sees many Reasons why he can∣not agree with the common Opinion of those whose Judgment he may in other Things acknowledge to be much better than his own, in that he cannot think it safe for the Government of Great Bri∣tain to go so hastily as the People seem to desire, and just at this time, about the Demolishing Dunkirk.

The Demolishing Dunkirk having been agreed upon in the late Treaty with the French King, and made a part of the Peace concluded at Ʋtrecht, it is no lon∣ger a Question, whether the French are obliged to Demolish it or not, if the Queen of Great Britain insists upon it; None will contend this part (viz.) that the French must and ought to perform what is so agreed; and the Town is put into the Queens Hand, to assure Her Majesty, on the part of France, that it shall be done when required.

There are not the same Reasons, or the same Obligations upon Her Majesty to Demolish Dunkirk, as there are upon the French King to do it if Her Majesty requires it; on the contrary, there are divers very good Reasons to be given why Her Majesty may not think it proper to suffer the said Fortifications to be YET Demolished.

The Enquiry therefore into the Vali∣dity of the Treaty, and how far the French King is oblig'd to Demolish Dun∣kirk if we insist upon it, is not the Case; but the Question before us is, WHE∣THER, as Dunkirk is now in Her Ma∣jesty's hand, and was given as a Pledge or Security to Great-Britain for the Per∣formance of those things stipulated by France on one hand, and to impower the Queen to do Her Subjects Right in the Netherlands, on the other hand; I say, whether it consists with common Pru∣dence to give up this Pledge before that Safety and Advantage which it was put into our hands to obtain and secure, be obtain'd and secured.

To enter fairly into this Argument, we must enquire, what were the true Mo∣tives upon which the British Court took Dunkirk into Possession? and why Her
Majesty insisted so steadily upon that Pos∣session preliminary so much as to any Engagement of Treating about a Peace? And perhaps the setting this matter right, may go a great way to the satisfying those People who now argue so hotly on this Point, and to the reconciling them to the Reasons which shall be aftetwards given.

It is true that, in the first place, the Restitution of Dunkirk was insisted upon as a Testimony to be given by the French King, that he was truly desirous of Peace; and sincerely resolved to give Satisfaction to Her Majesty and Her Allies; and, That Her Majesty should be Arbitress of what should or should not be esteem'd Satisfaction when a Treaty should be so commenc'd.

If in any thing the French King had not comply'd, if he had refused to grant any thing which Her Majesty judged es∣sential to the Safety and Peace of Europe, either which was insisted on by the Queen, or by Her Allies; Dunkirk was deem'd to be a sufficient Satisfaction to the Queen, and a sufficient Loss to France: So that leaving Dunkirk in Her Majesty's hands, he was at liberty to Treat or not to Treat, Conclude or not Conclude, as
he thought fit; since the Possession of Dunkirk was a thing so considerable to us, and in case of carrying on the War, would have been so fatal to France, that it required but a small Penetration to know that we had thereby the Key of France on that side put into our hands, and could, without any difficulty, have done what (however talk'd of) had been found so impracticable to bring to pass in 22 Years War, (viz.) to have carried the War into the Heart of France.

It should be next enquired, when the Article of putting Dunkirk into Her Ma∣jesty's hands was in Debate, from who and from what Foundation came the Ad∣dition of that Clause, (viz.) the Fortifi∣cations to be Demolished? Was it from the British, or from the French, or on some third Interest, that this part was pro∣posed?

No Man will be so weak as not to al∣low, that if the Town of Dunkirk, with all its Fortifications, Harbours, Peers, Rice-bank, Citadel, Bassin, & c. could have been obtain'd, and the Possession and Soveraignty of them made over to the Queen, the British Ministers would gladly have accepted it; nor could they have answer'd it to God and their Queen if they had not.

It was not then the British Ministers that demanded the Demolishing of Dun∣kirk, the gaining Possession of it, was their Point; which having obtain'd, they would never, if in their right Mind, have offer'd the Demolishing it, if it had not been insisted on by the French.

What Interest other Nations, our Al∣lies, have in this part, and how far they would be from being easy in the Town of Dunkirk's remaining in English hands un∣demolished, shall be enquired into after∣wards.

But for the present, this brief Obser∣vation may be drawn from the Premisses, (viz.) As it could not reasonably be our part to Article for the Demolishing Dun∣kirk when it was put into our hands; so neither can it be reasonable, that while we have it in Possession we should be more in haste to Demolish it, than other Nations.

The Case seems very clear, we have the Town in Possession: If it were never Demolished, what can the Hurt be on our fide? The Damage is to France, be∣cause they are deprived of it; and in case of any future Rupture with us, the Dan∣ger will be to them: But it is a most mysterious Suggestion, that the Fortifica∣tions
of Dunkirk should be dangerous to us who have them in Possession.
But this Mystery may perhaps be un∣folded more easily, when the Reason and Nature of Things comes to be a little far∣ther enquired into.

It is the Unhappiness of this Nation to be miserably divided into Parties; which Parties, have this one Peculiar which per∣haps distinguishes them from all that ever went before them, viz. That they agree in nothing: Many Divisions have been in this Nation and other Nations, and have been carried on to great heights, even to Blood and War; but still they determin'd what they differ'd in, and what they agreed in.

Thus the late Differences between Church and Dissenter, however warmly they differ'd, even to Persecution and Suf∣fering; yet they agreed to join against Po∣pery. The late Differences between Whig and Tory, Liberty and Arbitrary Power, ran very high; but they all join'd against Standing Armies, Dispensing Power, and the like.

But the People who differ now, seem to agree in nothing but to Dislike and Oppose whatever the other Party do, or espouse, meerly because done and espou∣sed
by them, without enquiring into the Reason and Merit of the Case; as if they were unwilling the opposite Party to them should have the Reputation of doing what is right, any more than the Power of do∣ing what is wrong.

But this seems to be a Temper fatal to the Publick Good, for that it is carried such a Length, that the Parties appear satisfied their Country should suffer the want of any Publick Service, rather than the Party who they oppose should be the Instruments in bringing it to pass.

This Digression appears necessary in this Place, as it will be hard to give any other rational Account; for the several parts of the Conduct of our People, with relation to the taking Possession, Keeping, and Demolishing of Dunkirk; and the Sinceri∣ty of the Complainers, must suffer great Reflection if the Particulars are well en∣quired into.

When first it was known that Dunkirk was to be deposited into Her Majesty's hands, the Friends of the Managers of that Affair began to magnify that Acqui∣sition, as a great Point gain'd; That it was a Service to the Kingdom, which could no other way have been brought to pass; That it was a sufficient Pledge that
they should be sincerely dealt with by the French King in the ensuing Treaty; and, That it ought to be taken for a Token of the real Concern the Ministry had for the Advantage of Great-Britain and their Ca∣pacity to shew it.

No sooner was this done, but the other Party, as if they opposed what was done because the other had done it; began im∣mediately to cry it down, to depreciate the thing it self, and give a wrong Ac∣count of the Circumstances: They repre∣sented Dunkirk as a thing of no great Con∣sequence; that as to our having it, it would cost us more to keep than it was worth, and would only serve the Mini∣stry for a Pretence to keep a Standing Army on foot, and the like. And as to the King of France, it was no such migh∣ty Loss to him; for, as the Town was to be restored to him when Demolished, he could easily restore the Works, and open the Harbour again: But that the Truth was, he was a-going to let us see he did not value it; that he was going to fortify Graveling, and would make it as Impregnable by Land as Dunkirk; and as to the Harbour, the Engineers had en∣gaged to make it a better, and to have two foot Water more in the Port than
in that of Dunkirk: So that Graveling would be every thing by Sea that Dunkirk was. These things were not the Publick Discourse of those People only, but were often printed and published in their seve∣ral Pamphlets and News-papers, as may be proved if there were occasion.

Now although this needed no other Confutation than Matter of Fact, viz. the Impracticableness of the Place (Grave∣ling) to make any such Harbour, and the reality of this Truth, viz. that no such thing is attempted, or indeed design'd by the French; yet these Reports have been industriously spread abroad, and kept up, tho' contradicted by uncontestable Evi∣dence; it being thought needful to lessen the Value of Dunkirk in the Eyes of the People, and consequently to lessen the Merit of those who struggled so much to get it into our hands, and esteem'd it of so great Advantage to us now it was obtain'd.

But one would have thought the Te∣stimony and Credit of the last Age should have establish'd our Opinion of Dunkirk in the present. When it was Sold by K. Charles II. to the present French King, how was the Politicks of that Reign cen∣sured for it? How is it recorded on seve∣ral
Accounts, as a Mark of Infamy upon the whole Court, and a Reproach to the Nation? What has the Memory of the Lord Chancellor Hyde suffer'd for being the Adviser of it, though he neither was guilty of it, nor did he forbear modestly to oppose it.

Then Dunkirk was called the Key of Commerce, a Door into France, a Muzzle or a Ring in the Nose of the Flemish-Lyon; its Value counted Inestimable, and the Nation betray'd in giving it over to the French. It was admirable to see the Voice of the Nation so suddenly changed; that when it was parted with, tho' at a great Price, it was raised up to such an intole∣rable Rate, and our Loss esteem'd so Irre∣parable; and yet the Town was of no great Strength at that time, and the Harbour of less Importance than that of Calais; as being capable to receive no Vessels of Bur∣then; and now, on the other hand, when it is acknowledged to be the most Important Place on this Side the World, the Portable to receive great Fleets, and to fit out Expe∣ditions to Invade us; the Town it self Im∣pregnable, and a Terror to all its Neigh∣bours; yet, on a sudden, the Price is fal∣len among our States-Men, and it is not
worth our taking, tho' we were to have it, as it were, for Nothing.

This is an unanswerable Evidence of the Power of our Divisions, and how the Prejudices that are among us Influence our Judgments to Argue even against Light, and against the Conviction of our own Reason.

We can hardly express how much we are beholding in this Matter to the worthy Mr. Steele, the publisher of the Guardian, No. 128. I will not be so unjust to him as to call him the Author; who has effectu∣ally set us right in this Matter, and has rescued the Town and Harbour of Dun∣kirk from the depreciating Arts of our Party-Men, who, it was to be fear'd, would have brought it at last so low, that we might have been made believe the King of France, if we should offer to give it him again, would not accept of it.

But the Guardian has taken the Cou∣rage to do Justice to the Dunkirkers, and of Consequence to the Ministry, in securing such a Place in the Possession of the Queen; for he has told us expresly, that to take Dunkirk from the French is removing France two or three hundred Miles fur∣ther from us; that they have not any Port where they can sit out any Fleet till they
come to Brest; that it is of the last Con∣sequence to Britain that it should no more be in the French Power, that the In∣jury we have received from them is In∣estimable. His words follow.

“That when Dunkirk is demolished, the Power of France, on that Side, should it ever be turned against us, will be removed several hundred Miles further off of Great-Britain than it is at present. Vide Guardian, No. 128.

As this is an undoubted Testimony gi∣ven to the Zeal of the Ministry, in taking hold of the present Conjuncture, to get that Important Fortress into our Hands, and is the greatest and most just Panegy∣rick which Mr. Steele ever made upon any great Action in the World, and which, no doubt, he did in Honour to the Queen, and the present Government; and that the said Mr. Steele has gained the just Ap∣probation of all her Majesty's good Sub∣jects for so doing, so it is a fair Confuta∣tion of all those weak Things which had been advanced by a Party among us, in Prejudice of the late Negociations; but above all, that it is an unanswerable Argu∣ment against our too soon parting with,
or too hastily Demolishing this Important Place, which is of such Consequence to the Nation; and I cannot doubt, but Mr. Steele did it that Justice with this Intent. For it is impossible a Man of his Penetration, and of his exquisite Po∣liticks, could Argue for our immediate putting the Place out of our Possession, because it was a Place of very great Con∣sequence, and that the Security of Great-Britain depended on it. This will always be allow'd to be a good Argument with any true Britain, why we should get it into our Possession, and why we should keep it now we have it, at least till we are effectually Secured; but it will be very hard to make this pass with any reasona∣ble Man for an Argument, why we should pull it to pieces, and give it away again to France; and, God be praised, those who are of that mind have not the Town in their Possession, nor the Power to de∣stroy our Security, before the Thing to be Secur'd by it be actually obtain'd.

Having therefore so good a Testimony to the Value of the Thing, we shall not need to say any thing to do Justice to those Councils who manag'd France so, as to get a Town of that Consequence put into our Hands.

But to return to the Parties among us, and the Designs which we now see mana∣ged by them, one against another. When they found that depreciating and run∣ning down the Value of Dunkirk would do them no Service, that their own Com∣plaints formerly, when it was first parted with to the French, contradicted it, and that the real Importance of the Place was so well known to every one, that it be∣came ridiculous to attempt the making Peo∣ple believe otherwise; they took other Measures.

First, They endeavoured to make it be believed, that we had not really gotten Possession of it, that the French held the principal Parts of it, that the Garrison was restrain'd by the Burghers, that the French could Dispossess them of it when they pleased; and the like.

This also their Flying-Post and other Libels Published for a certain Truth, tho' the Fact was quite otherwife from the beginning. The English Troops being put into an immediate Possession of every part of the Town, the Cittadel, Rice-Bank, all the Gates, the two Peers, every Out∣work, and also of Fort-Louis, at a good distance from the Town; so that there was not the least part left in Possession of the French, nor were any French Troops
left in the Place, except a few Ma∣rines, who were appointed to guard the old unrigged Gallies and Men of War which lay in the Basin, and which could not be carryed away, and which being but meer Hulks, it was necessary to keep a small Guard upon them, to keep the People of the Town from pulling them in pieces.

A little Time therefore discovering the Truth, this Shift would serve no longer, and so was abandon'd for a quite con∣trary extream; for, on a sudden, the very same People who had run down Dunkirk, as good for nothing, or to use their own Words, of no great Consequence, not worth having, and the like; turn'd their Tale, and Dunkirk was now of the utmost Consequence in the World.

It was with some Impatience, that the On-Looking and Impartial part of Man∣kind waited to know what they would infer from this new Opinion, for every one allow'd they were now in the right; That Dunkirk was of the last Importance, no Body could question; But what could they draw from thence?

To say that therefore the Ministry had acted Wisely in getting so great and so terrible a Place out of the Hands of so
dangerous a Person as the French King, without Blood or Blows, to have it qui∣etly Surrendered and put into our Hands as a pledge of Peace; that a Fortress which had been so fatal to us, was now secured, whatever might happen, from ever doing Britain any more Mischief; this went against their Nature, and the very Thoughts of it made their Party-Blood run cold within them.

As this therefore could not be expected from them, so no Man in the World could ever have believed, that from the Acknowledgment of its Importance, could be drawn an Argument for our throwing it out of our Hands.

If they had said they would have it Demolished, because the Dutch are not willing we should keep it; because the Flemings are not willing to have us be so much their Masters; because the Em∣peror does not care to Trust us with it; because by it you are able to Establish the English Trade in Flanders, whether the States-General approve of it or no. These are Reasons which have some Force in them, and which out of the Mouth of a Dutchman, or an Imperialist, would be very Rational. But for Englishmen to Argue thus has something unnatural in
it, and looks as if those People had more regard to the Interest of Holland, or the Emperor, than to their own Country.

But so it is; and let there be Reason in it or no Reason in it, force of Argu∣ment or no force of Argument, we must give them leave to make it popular, that Dunkirk must immediately be Demo∣lished, and given back to the French; because it is of the greatest Importance to us in the World; which, on the con∣trary, we say is the very Reason why it should not be Demolished till all those Things are secured and obtained for which it was at first put into our Hands. And whatever the Clamour of these Men may be, it is still hoped the Government, whose Business it is not to do what these People seek, but what it is reasonable and just they should do for the Publick Good, will consider well what other Things, absolutely necessary to be done for the good of the Nation, ought to be finished, before Dunkirk be Demolished.

And that we may not be amused with Generals, any more on one Side than another, it may be very useful to set down some particular Reasons why Dun∣kirk ought not yet to be Demolished; if the other People can assign better Rea∣sons
why it should be immediately done the World will easily be convinced; and, in the mean time, the Nation will have leisure to Judge on either Side.

Besides what has been said of the Rea∣sons why Dunkirk was Deposited by the French in the Hands of Her Majesty, at the beginning of the Treaty; it is to be enquired what other Reasons there were why Her Majesty insisted on that Surren∣der. I shall put them all together.
I. The Reasons which respected France.
II. The Reasons which respected Britain.

Putting the Sincerity of the French King, in his Proposals for a Treaty, out of doubt. A Security against the French King's breaking in upon any of the Preliminaries before the Treaty was concluded. A Security for the Perfor∣mance of the Treaty it self, of which this was an effectual Preliminary.
These were the Reasons on the French King's part, in general, why he should Surrender Dunkirk to the Allies.
But these were not the Reasons why Dunkirk should be Deposited in the Hands of the Queen of Great-Britain more than any other of the Allies: The Reasons for that were such as these.

1. That the Queen of Great-Britain, who had given her Opinion, and declared her Resolution for a Treaty of Peace, and had signified so much to her Allies, might be very well assured that the Satisfaction which her Majesty was resolved to en∣deavour to procure for her said Allies, and which France had proposed to give; should be really and Bona fide performed on the part of France.

2. That the British Commerce which remained unsettled in the Low-Countries, and which the Dutch, by reason of the large extent of their Barrier in Flanders, had the power to interrupt, might not be so much at the Mercy either of the Dutch, or the Emperor, as otherwise it would be.

From a further Examination of these Particulars, it will appear, that there are very good and sufficient Reasons why the Queen of Great-Britain ought not to Demolish Dunkirk, or part with that Power which is in Her Hands, to do Herself and Her Subjects Right, as well in the Matter of Commerce, as of other Things, till those Things are fully settled to Her Satisfaction. Let us enquire into them more particularly.

The Reason why the Demolishing of Dunkirk was limited to a Time, was on a Supposition that the Peace would have been General, and that the Emperor should accept such Conditions as were judged reasonable by the other Powers then in Alliance with him. This his Imperial Majesty has not thought fit to do; but the War is going on: If, on the one hand, the Arms of France are like to be Victo∣rious, the Queen has no tye upon the French, to bring them to grant Terms of Accommodation to Germany, and to restore their Conquest, but the keeping the Town of Dunkirk in her Hands; which the French will be very loth to submit to or suffer; for it is a gross vul∣gar Mistake, to think that not to Demo∣lish Dunkirk is a favour to France; and we shall soon find the King of France insist upon its being Demolished, since it is out of his Hand, if he should but imagine that the English Design to keep it.

On the other hand, while the War is continued between the Emperor and France, it may be possible, tho' not at all proba∣ble, that the Emperor's Arms may be Suc∣cessful: If such an unlikely Thing should happen, let any one judge whether it were proper that her Majesty should be
quite shut out of Flanders, and have no other Influence on Affairs than what should be at the good liking of either Party.

For which Reason, I cannot think any Man that has the Honour and Interest of Great-Britain at Heart, can desire that this Important Pledge of Europe's Peace ought to be put out of Her Majesty's Hand, till the Emperor and the French King have decided their Quarrel, and till the Peace of Europe is compleatly Established: And this is one Reason.

2. The Treaties of Barrier, and other Engagements between the Queen of Great-Britain and the States-General, of which so much stir has been made and by which our Trade to Flanders is to be set∣tled and regulated, neither are, nor can be yet, nor perhaps for some considerable time made so Effectual, as that we may be able to say we shall have a fair and equal Regulation of Commerce in Flan∣ders. The Refractory and Disobliging Behaviour of the Flemings, even while our Troops have been in Possession of their Country. The Conduct of the Council of State there, while the Civil Government has been provisionally in the Hands of the Queen, and the States-General.
These all give us Reason to see, that we have nothing to expect from them but what we have Power to ob∣tain, by doing our selves Justice. How far the Dutch will do us Justice in such part as shall be in their Hands, I will not undertake to determine beforehand, but no true Britain will contend that we ought not to leave the British Commerce in Flanders at the Mercy either of one or other: And this is a second Reason why I think we ought not to divest ourselves of so great an Advantage as the Possession of Dunkirk is, by which we may be al∣ways in a Condition to do our selves right, if others refuse it, till we see our Commerce setled, and the English Trade in Flanders regulated upon an equal Foot with the Dutch, as it was agreed to be, and as it is, but just and equal that it should be.

If any one think that this Reason is not good, I refer them back to the Par∣liament, who were so sensible of the Value of our Trade there, and of the un∣equal Terms we should stand upon, if we were quite divested of a Footing in Flanders, that they Addressed Her Majesty not to part with any Thing She was pos∣sessed of in Flanders, till the Trade of Her Subjects was effectually Secured. What those People mean, and whose In∣terest
they are acting, contrary to that of their own Country, who are for having Her Majesty give up and Demolish Dun∣kirk before these Things are settled, and before sufficient Security for our Trade is made and obtain'd will easily appear; nor can they ever Answer the Charge of referring the Interest of the Dutch, and the Emperor, to that of their own Country. The Resolution of the Parliament in this Case, is as follows.

Resolved, “That an humble Address be presented to Her Majesty, That She will be pleased to take Care, that the Towns in Flanders, in Her Majesty's Possession, be not evacuated, till those who are to have the Sovereignty of the Spanish Netherlands agree to such Articles for regulating of Trade, as may put the Subjects of Great-Britain upon an equal Foot with those of any other Nation. Vide Votes, 22 June, 1713.”

After such an Authority as this, What Man can have the Face to say, the BRI∣TISH NATION EXPECTS Dunkirk to be immediately Demolished? the House of Commons is the Representative of the BRITISH NATION, and, it is plain, they expect the contrary, and have Ad∣dressed Her Majesty to the contrary; and, I doubt not, but if some Powers go on as they have begun, and continue
to show the little Inclination they have to do Justice to Her Majesty, or Her Subjects, the House of Commons may come, in time, to Address Her Majesty not to suffer Dunkirk to be Demolished at all, till Right be done; at least, they would have little cause to Thank those who should go about to Demolish it, till all that we ought to expect be done, and the Liberty and Conditions of our Trade in Flanders, sufficiently and effectually Secured to us.

3. The Third Case is this: The Pos∣session of Dunkirk being, as was said, a Pledge of the Sincerity of the French King, in the Affair of the Treaty, so was it also a Pledge of the Conditions agreed on by His most Christian Majesty to Her Majesty the Queen of Great-Britain; and for this Reason, it cannot be EXPECTED, even by His most Christian Majesty himself, that Her Majesty should suffer Dunkirk to be Demolished till the Conditions of the said Treaty, on the part of His said most Christian Majesty, shall be fully Executed in all the Parts thereof; particularly the Treaty of Commerce, which having met with some Obstruction here, has not been brought into Practice, and cannot be for some time, at least, not till the Meeting of the next Parliament. Now, tho' the French King indeed might Complain, and
say, that he being ready to execute the Treaty upon his part, and the delay be∣ing on the British Side only, it was not reasonable to keep His Town of Dunkirk from Him, or to delay the Demolishing of it upon an occasion which had its Original wholly in our selves, and might therefore Demand that it be immediately Demolished, according to the Treaty; Yet it is unaccountable how this can be an Argument on our Side, and that the People of Britain should be impatient to put out of their own Hand what is their Security, for the performance of the Terms of Peace and Trade; and the unaccounta∣bleness of this confirms what is before suggested, viz. That these Men are car∣rying on the Interest, of another People, not of their own Country.

There is no doubt, but the Dutch, the Emperor, the Flemings, and all that are in their Interest, would be glad to have Dun∣kirk out of Her Majesty's Possession; if it had been in their Choice, it should never have come into Her Hands; nor can they be much blamed for it, there are many Things to be said for it on their Side.

But what an Englishman can say for it, why he should desire it, especially before every Thing, for which it is a Security,
is really Secured, is an unaccountable My∣stery, and can never be unfolded, but very much to the Disadvantage of the People who are concerned in it: What can a Subject of Great-Britain Plead, why he should be in such great hast to have Dunkirk Demolished? If he has the true Interest of his Country at his Heart, he cannot but desire Great-Britain should keep the Hold it has of any Foreign Power, whereby it may oblige them to do his Country Justice, till that Justice is obtain'd.

There is but one Thing left to those People to Plead, and this, altho' they will secretly acknowledge that they have it in their View, yet they care not to acknowledge they entertain any Thought so bad in their Hearts, viz. That they suggest France, and the present Govern∣ment, to be so much in one Interest, that this Important Fortress shall be again put into the Hands of the King of France, or Subjected to his Interest upon all Occa∣sions, tho' in prejudice of the British In∣terest; but this is so unnatural a Thing, I care not to say more of it here; it were to be wished there were no Cause to have said so much.
Upon the whole, the Case is this, as to Dunkirk: It is our Security for the Per∣formance of the Articles of Peace.
It is Europe's Security, that France shall give good Terms of Peace to the House of Austria, tho' his Arms should be Vic∣torious
It is the Security of our Commerce in Flanders, which is not yet setled.
And till all these Things are brought to a Conclusion, it would be most unreasona∣ble to EXPECT, that Dunkirk should be Demolished.

Whoever he was therefore who put that Letter into the GƲARDIAN, perempto∣rily telling the Government, that the Bri∣tish Nation EXPECTED Dunkirk should be IMMEDIATELY Demolished, was guil∣ty of the following Crimes.
1. Insolence, and want both of Manners and Duty to the Queen, in giving such Language to his Soveraign, on so ill-grounded an Occasion.
2. Falshood, in speaking that, in the Name of the British-Nation, which they neither gave him Authority to do, or which the Nature of Things made reasonable.
3. Sedition, in stirring up the People to Mutiny and Disaffection, when there has not been the least occasion of Discontent given.
4. Absurdity, in Arguing for that, which it is the most reasonable Thing in the World, that every true Britain should Ar∣gue against and Oppose▪

1. Insolence, and want of Manners and Duty to the Queen. I am sorry to say this is grown so fashionable a Crime now, among those who pretend to be most zea∣lous for the Publick Good, that it is suffi∣cient to mark a Man out as an Enemy to that Publick Good, to complain of their using the Queen Ill; as if the Respect and Veneration due to the Person of their Sove∣raign, lessen'd that just Zeal and Fidelity which an Honest Man bears always in his Heart for, and to the true Interest of his Country. What the GƲARDIAN has shewn of this kind, is but a light Excursion, com∣pared to what is to be found in the general Conversation of those Men who are so warm for the Demolishing of Dunkirk; and I Note it here, because it is the very Argument they use for the more immedi∣ate Demolishing Dunkirk, viz. Their Di∣strust of the Queen Herself: and I do them no wrong when I say, that if in private Conversation you ask them what makes them so uneasie about Dunkirk, and if they dare not trust the Queen with the keeping it, they will not refrain to Answer readily and plainly, No. That the Con∣cern Her Majesty has shewen for the Safety and Welfare of Her People has deserved better Usage, is known very well, even to
these Men themselves; and it cannot be spoken without great Resentment in the Minds of all her Majesty's true and faith∣ful Subjects. But this Use I shall make of it here, viz. That those People merit much less than the Queen to be trusted either with the Keeping of Dunkirk, or with any other Power in this Nation; I forbear saying more to it, because the Business of this Tract is rather to Convince than Expose them, it is hoped that when they see Dunkirk Demo∣lish'd, as in its proper time there is no Reason to doubt it will be, or so conce∣ded to this Nation, that it shall not be in the Power even of the Crown it self, to restore it to France; I say, when this appears, these Men will see great Reason to blush for their present Conduct, and to be asham'd as well of their Treating her Majesty in such an undutiful manner, as of their pretended Fears of Dunkirk's being restored to the French.

2. But this is not all; the Guardian is also guilty of Falshood, in speaking what is really not true in Fact; viz. That the British Nation expects Dunkirk should be immediately Demolished. As there can∣not be a greater Blemish on the Character of a Gentleman, than not to speak Truth, for which Reason the giving the LYE to
a Gentleman is counted the grossest Af∣front that can be offer'd; so really no∣thing ought to be a Gentleman's Care more than always to speak the Truth, and not lay his Reputation open even to the nicest Reprover, as to his Veracity. That the Guardian has not taken this Care, let the World judge when they read his said Paper, Guardian No. 128. Aug. 7. The British Nation expects the IMMEDIATE Demolishing of Dunkirk; when at the same time he could not but know, that the Parliament, the two Houses of Lords and Commons, which may be more properly called the British Nation than any Body of People whose Assent could be obtain'd to that Assertion, and that these did not EXPECT it: If then I prove that the Parliament did not Expect it, I hope I may be allow'd to say, with as much De∣cency as I can, That what the Guardian has said, is FALSE.
Now that the Parliament did not Ex∣pect it, appears,
1. By the aforesaid Address to her Majesty, to keep Possession of what she held in Flanders till the British Trade was settled and secured.
2. By the Parliament granting Mony to Subsist the Garrison of Dunkirk to next Christmas.

It cannot be possible that the Parlia∣ment EXPECTED Dunkirk should be immediately Demolished, and at the same time gave Mony to pay the Garrison that was to keep it till Christmas next; that were to make them EXPECT one thing, and DIRECT another.

What can be more Convincing than this? And how was it possible the Au∣thor of the Guardian could be guilty of so wide a Step from the Honour and Truth which ought to be the denomina∣ting Quality of a Gentleman?

Can it be pleaded, that the Parliament is not to be called the British Nation? Let him tell us then, who are the British Nation; and let him tell us, how he as∣sum'd so much upon Truth and Honour as to say the British Nation, when he knew he spoke but the Sence of a Party, that Party but few, and that few Ig∣norant of the true Reasons why Dun∣kirk was not yet to be Demolished; nay it is rather to be feared, he gave the De∣nomination of the British Nation to his own grave Self, and a little Party of a Party whose Idol he was fond of appear∣ing to be, and that he is so far from being able to prove what he asserts, viz. that the British Nation expects, & c. that he cannot prove he had any Authority, but
from his own Notion, to publish any thing of that nature in the Names of any part of the British Nation.

There has not been so accumulated a Guilt in any Forgery published in this Age, by which a Man who was thought to be a Gentleman, however at this time he had descended to the Rank of a De∣ceiver, could ever have Imposed upon a Nation as he has done; and as he promi∣ses himself to be a Member of Parliament in the present Election, it is not doubted but that Honorable House will do Justice in the Case when it comes before them.

3. The next Charge upon the Publish∣er of that Letter in the Guardian, is Se∣dition. It is true the Charge is high, and but one Step short of Treason; and ought to be well grounded before it be laid home to a Person. I take Sedition o consist, among other things, of this; (viz.) Spreading groundless and false Suggestions among the People, knowing those Suggestions to be false, with Design to amuse the said People, and stir them up to Discontent at the Government they live under.

That the Suggestion spread by the Guardian was false and groundless, I think is made evident, and cannot be deny'd: How the Guardian will come off from the last part, viz. that this was spread
abroad among the People, to stir them up to Murmur at the Goverment because Dunkirk was not immediately Demolish∣ed, he best knows. The best way that I know to clear him is, to have him tell us what other End he could have in it, and then prove he had such Ends as he proposes. It is very plain, the Publish∣ing it was to stir up the People to Cla∣mour and Discontent; and what else is the Repetition every Day in the Flying-Post, viz. Dunkirk is not yet begun to be Demolished? Alas! do these Scribblers think to Bully the Queen and the Ministry in∣to the doing it before it is proper to do it? No, they are not so foolish; but they hope to stir up a Clamour among the Peo∣ple, and a general Discontent at its not being done; and this is SEDITION. Should the Ministry have Weakness e∣nough to be moved by these Seditious Clamours, and fall into the Snare of gi∣ving up the Fortifications of Dunkirk to be Demolished, before they had obtained the Performance of all things for which Dunkirk was a Pledge, these Men would be the first to fall upon the Ministry for neglecting the Publick Safety, and for gi∣ving up the Security before the Things for which it was a Security are obtain'd. And this brings in the fourth part of the
Charge on the Guardian and his Party, viz.

4. The ABSURDITY of it. And to argue coolly on that Head, What can be more absurd, than the desiring the Ministry to quit the Possession of the only thing which is their Security for the making good the Treaties of Peace and Com∣merce, and their Security against Miscon∣structions in the Executing the said Trea∣ties on the Part of France? Would they not all say, that this was to have no Treaty at all, and that it was to put it out of our Power to oblige the French King to the Performance? And what Treatment must the Ministers have expected from the same Men who now make this Com∣plaint, if they had been so weak to do thus?
It is said here, by way of Objection, That the Time for beginning to Demo∣lish it is stipulated in express Terms in the Treaty; viz.

“The most Christian King shall take Care, that all the Fortifications of the City of Dunkirk be razed, that the Har∣bour be fill'd up, and that the Sluices or Moles which serve to cleanse the Harbour be Levelled, and that at the said King's own Expence, within the space of five Months after the Condi∣tions
of Peace are Concluded and Signed.”

What can be more against them than this Allegation? It is evident this is a Sti∣pulation on the part of France, viz. That he shall not be obliged to begin the Work sooner; and on the part of the Queen of Great-Britain, That if her Majesty deman∣ded it, he should be oblig'd to begin it so soon: But no way obliging the Queen of Great-Britain, that whether all other Things were done or not, her Majesty should be bound to let it be Demolished so soon.

The very nature of the thing is quite otherwise; If a Security be consign'd over for the Performance of a Condition, and any thing happens to delay the Perfor∣mance of that Condition; if the Security is not to remain, how shall the Perfor∣mance of the Condition be ascertain'd to the Person to whom it was to be done?

Here are Conditions of the Treaty not made Effectual, the Treaty of Commerce is delay'd here; the Emperor is not yet come into the Peace, by which means the Government and Trade of the late Spanish now Imperial Netherlands is not settled, or the British Interest there secured: The Parliament has been so sensible of the Danger to Great Britain from this Posture
of Affairs there, that they have desired her Majesty to keep more Footing in Flanders, rather than less, till that Mat∣ter is secured: Can it be thought the Par∣liament would have been willing Dunkirk should have been thrown up, when they were willing Newport and other Towns should be possess'd till the Queen had Sa∣tisfaction, and till our Trade was secured on that side? What Thanks would any succeeding Parliament of Britain have gi∣ven a Ministry, that when the House of Commons had desired her Majesty to keep Possession of what she held in Flanders, should give up Dunkirk, which was more than all the rest, and the keeping of which was the only way to enable Her to keep all the rest, and more especially when the said Parliament had made Provision of Mony particularly and expresly for the paying the Expence of keeping Dunkirk till Christmas next, if it should be needful.

Is not this as much as if the Parliament had said to the Queen, Madam, Since the Treaty of Commerce has been delay'd, and must of course come to be debated by another Parliament; since the Emperor has not thought fit to come into the Peace, by which means the Government of Flanders, &c. is not yet set∣tled, and the British Commerce there is not regulated; we desire Your Majesty to keep the
Town of Dunkirk in your Hands, and not Demolish the same till the Meeting of the next Parliament, and that it shall be determin'd in Parliament what shall or may be thought proper to be done with it, whether Demolished or not, as the situation of Affairs shall then appear to be; and that Your Majesty may the better be Enabled to do this, your Loyal and Faith∣ful Commons have made Provision for the Mainte∣nance of the Garrison till that time, or till Christ∣mas, which is supposed to be near the time when another Parliament will assemble.
Let Mr. Guardian be the Judge himself, whe∣ther this be not the true state of the Case, and whether he has any Wrong done him in expo∣sing what he has published as the greatest Ab∣surdity imaginable.
Thus the Proposal of immediately Demolish∣ing Dunkirk, seems to me to be sufficiently pro∣ved, according to the four Heads above writ∣ten, to be Unmannerly, False, Seditious, and Ridiculous.
From what has been said, the Author desires to draw some Inferences, and defend himself against some other which the Partiality of Man∣kind may be pleased to draw from it. I begin with the latter.
1. It does by no means follow from what has been said, that Dunkirk is not to be Demolished at all.
2. Less yet does it follow from hence, that it is to be delivered back to the French whole and undismantled.
3. And least of all does it follow, that it is to be kept in Concert between Britain and France for private Designs too ridiculous as well as too malicious to be nam'd.

These Things had not been mentioned, but that the People who began the aforesaid Reflecti∣ons have not been backward, however groundless, to insist upon them all, and to make use of them upon sundry Party-occasions, as the several De∣signs now carrying on require.

It can scarce be admitted within the Limits of Charity, to suppose that any one should suggest Things so unnatural of the present Government; and we cannot wonder that the worst and most scandalous Things in the World should be charged upon them, when we see Things so criminal, as well as so contrary to their Interest, suggested.

It would be hard to assign a Reason why the Ministry should take a Step so dangerous to them∣selves, as well as so disgusting to the Generality of the Nation, as that of giving back Dunkirk to the French King undemolish'd: If they are so much in the French Interest as to be willing to gratify the French King in any thing he desires, which is the Crime their Enemies would willing∣ly fasten upon them, or at least would have the People believe; why then had they not made the Treaty with him without taking Dunkirk at all? If they had been so willing to have oblig'd the French King, that had been the proper time; then it might have been past over without so much notice, and they might have accepted of some Equivalent less to the French King's Disadvan∣tage, and perhaps equally, if not more, satis∣factory to the other Allies than that of Dunkirk Why did they insist upon such a Pledge for the French King's Performance of Conditions? A Pledge, which it is well known, the French did not part with but with the umost Difficulty, and with the greatest Reluctance imaginable. It had
been easy to have gratified the French King at that time, without giving so general a Distaste, and at least without having it lie as a particular Charge upon them. If the City of Lisle had been left to the Dutch instead of Dunkirk, and as an Equivalent, it can scarce be doubted but the States-General would have been made full as easy as at having Dunkirk put into the Hands of the English; and no question the French King would have given some Millions to have made the Exchange: So that if the Design had been to have given back Dunkirk to the French undisman∣tled, the Ministry could have gratify'd the French with leaving it in their Hands at first, much bet∣ter and much more to their own Safety, than they can restore it again after they have gotten it: Nor is it rational to think that the British Govern∣ment, who so strenuously and so immovably in∣sisted, at the time of the Treaty, on the Condi∣tion of having Dunkirk delivered up to them as a Pledge for the Security of the Performance of the other part of the Treaty, should now deli∣ver it back to the French Undemolish'd. Can any one believe that the Memory of its being parted with to France formerly, and the Reproach, tho' unjustly too, which was cast on the Reputation of the late Lord Chancellor Hyde for being instru∣mental in the Bargain and Sale of Dunkirk, is not recent enough in the Memory of our Mini∣stry to move them to avoid splitting their Cha∣racters on such a Rock? If the Ministry had no Regard to the Safety and Honour of their Coun∣try in the Treaty, why did they steddily insist upon having Dunkirk put into their Hands? And if they had so much Concern for the Interest and Honour of Great-Britain, as to refuse all Condi∣tions
of a Treaty without that important Point, why should they be suspected of so much Weak∣ness, as well as Unfaithfulness to their said Coun∣try, as to give it back again? The Charge does not seem to be supported by Reason; besides, it is very unjust and unfair to suppose such a thing when the very Suggestion of it is so unnatural and improbable.

2. As to the Opinion of its being in the De∣sign of the Ministry not to Demolish it at all; it does not seem to have any Foundation in the Reason and Nature of the Thing, unless the French King should not punctually and honora∣bly perform the Conditions of his Treaty, ac∣cording to the true Intent and Meaning of the Treaty; and in such case, no true Britain, faith∣ful to the Interest of his Country, can give his Consent to the Demolishing Dunkirk: In the mean time, 'tis a marvellous thing that we should have Men among us, who should desire to have the Queen of Great-Britain divest her self of the Power she has now in her Hands to enforce the Treaty, and to oblige the French to perform the Conditions. To have the French King willing that Dunkirk should be first Demolished, and un∣easy that he is not permitted to go about it; this would be rational, and what might be ex∣pected: but, that the English, the British Nation, People who pretend to be concern'd for the Ho∣nour and Interest of their Country; to have these be uneasy, and in haste to have Dunkirk Demolished, this is really admirable, and the Occasion of it unaccountable.

3 dly, As to keeping it in Concert between Great-Britain and France, for private Designs: When those private Designs are rationally suggested,
some Reply may be made; but at present it is so incongruous and weak a Suggestion, that it merits no Answer at all.
A few Observations then may serve to set us right in this Matter.

1. There is no reason to doubt, but that when the Conditions of the Treaty of Peace are perform'd, our Commerce secured, the Peace of this part of Europe Established, and the Dangers that we may justly apprehend from the War, yet depending between the Emperor and the French King at an End, Dunkirk will be Demolished; I say, there is no Cause to fear it, for two Reasons, (1.) Be∣cause there is no doubt but the French King will insist upon it, and be very ill satisfied if it is not done. (2.) Because Her Majesty being a Just, a Righteous, and a Christian Queen, and ha∣ving Capitulated with the French to suffer it to be done, it cannot without great Indecency be suggested, that those Capitulations shall not be performed. If no just Reasons drawn from the Non-performance of Articles on the other Side, shall occur to make it just and reasonable not to do it.

2. If such reasonable Obstructions should hap∣pen, as should make it necessary to keep the Pledge, as a farther Security, of which also the Parliament may be Judges, it would be very un∣accountable to suggest, especially by a Subject of Britain, that it should not be safe in our OWN Hands; and indeed, this makes the Complaint appear so wonderful among us, viz. That it should not be safe for Her Majesty to keep Dunkirk in Her OWN Hands; and, it is to be fear'd, those that think so, do not think it safe for the Queen
to keep the Crown in Her own Hands; they would do well to speak plain, and tell us.
1st. Would they have it Demolished before the Conditions, for which it is a Security, are per∣form'd?
2 dly. Whose Hand would they think it safe to have it kept by in the mean time, if not in our own Hands; and why not in our Hands, to whom the said Conditions are to be perform'd?

But let us come to the main Point, and suppose it were never to be Demolished at all, and so advantagious an Article had been obtain'd, that Great-Britain should have been Mistress of one of the best Ports made by Art, and the strongest Fortresses in the World; Had this been our Loss or our inestimable Advantage? Sure the like Ar∣gument to this was never used, in any Case of this Nature, in the Memory of Man, or beyond it; that the most impregnable Fortification of the Low-Countries, the most advantagious Port of the whole Western part of the World, the Curb of France, the Bridle of the Flemings, the Terror of the Hol∣lander, and that has been the Plague of Great-Bri∣tain, should be put into our OWN Hands, and we should be afraid to keep it.

Were it possible to bring the French King to consent that the Queen should keep Possession of the Town of Dunkirk, with all its Fortifications. What Minister of State could Answer it to his Country, or his Honour, to refuse or neglect se∣curing such a Thing to the Nation? And what Englishman, or what Subject, faithful to the Inte∣rest of Great-Britain, but would rejoyce to see such an addition of Strength made to the British Empire? But an unhappy Spirit now reigning among us, runs
up Things to such a highth of Dissention, that we are made afraid of our selves; afraid that those who are Intrusted by Heaven with the Crown it self, should be Intrusted by us with the keeping of Dunkirk, nay, with the keeping it till we can be safe in Surrendering and Demolishing it: A little Time will fully expose the Folly of this Notion, and let us see not the Necessity of keeping it a while only, but the Infinite Glory and Advantage it would bring to Great-Britain, if once more the Important Town of Dunkirk could be united to the British Empire.

One of the weak and absurd Objections against it, and which it is wonderful wise Men are not asham'd to mention, is the Charge of keeping it; as if the Importance of the Place was not infinitely greater than the Expence of maintaining it can be; and this is still more foolish, because it is well known the Customs of the Harbour of Dunkirk will always be sufficient to pay the Gar∣rison, and all the Expence of the Fortifications, and much more; but if it were not so, the Argu∣ment is of no Force at all.

3 dly. That it will be a pretence for keeping up a standing Force: This is equally absurd with the former, because the Garrison of Dunkirk being li∣mited to a certain Number of Men, just as many as are sufficient to its necessary Defence, it will always be necessary to keep them there, since a full Garrison, such as in Case of a Siege would be needful, might not be needful to be always there, the Sea being at our Command, and we always ready to supply the Place from England out of the standing Forces which are allowed; or a certain Number of those Established Forces might be always added to the usual Garrison, which
indeed would always make our Establishment less, rather than more.

The present Ministry have shew'd so little In∣clination to Govern by a standing Army, and, on the contrary, have given such an undisputed Tes∣timony to prove that they are Enemies to a stand∣ing Army, that it is not without the greatest Injustice, that such a Thought of them can be entertain'd, seeing they have appointed the Esta∣blishment of Great-Britain to be Two thousand Men less than was appointed after the Peace of Ryswick.

I see no Argument of any Force remaining, to urge the speedy Demolishing of Dunkirk, or the Demolishing it all, if it could be preserved in our own Possession; our dear bought Experience might have admonished us in such a Case, since we so hastily dismantled Tangier, which was an infinite Detriment and Disadvantage to us, during the last War, especially till Gibraltar, by an un∣expected and unforeseen Casualty, fell into our Hands; and it is wonderful, our People who are so willing to have Dunkirk out of our Hands, should not have the same Passion to discharge us of Gibraltar and Port-Mahon, the Arguments be∣ing much the same, as to Expence of keeping and standing Forces; but we hope, in a short while, we shall see our own Interest more clearly; and if ever a War should be renew'd in this part of the World, and Dunkirk should be ours, we should be presently convinced of the Consequence of it.

In a word, the Case is this: If we must be forced to Demolish Dunkirk, we must do it be∣cause we are engaged to do it, after all Conditions
of Peace and Commerce are performed and se∣cured; but if it could be obtain'd to Great-Bri∣tain, to keep it as our own, it would be an inex∣pressible Honour and Advantage to the whole Kingdom: The Particulars of what Advantage it would be, are reserved for a larger Descrip∣tion.
